document_metadata.name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the leading cause of dementia in the elderly.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: AD is a chronic neurodegenerative disease characterized by the progressive deposition of the amyloid b (Ab) in the parenchyma of the brain.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The ApoE4 allele is most important genetic risk factor for AD, while the ApoE2 allele is thought to be protective.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The ApoE4 allele is most important genetic risk factor for AD, while the ApoE2 allele is thought to be protective.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: In this study, it was shown that samples from human AD brains as well as two aged mouse models of AD showed increased mRNA levels of the M2 markers, Arg1 and Ym1, when compared to age matched controls [101].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: AD is a chronic neurodegenerative disease characterized by the progressive deposition of the amyloid b (Ab) in the parenchyma of the brain.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: It has been postulated that soluble or small oligomeric forms of Ab have deleterious effects in the brain, inducing impaired synaptic function and promoting neuronal degeneration [5].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The development of dense-core amyloid plaques is associated with a robust immune response mediated by microglial cells.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The appearance of amyloid deposition in the AD brain coincides with a dramatic phenotypic activation of microglial cells in the surrounding area.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The plaque-associated microglia secrete a variety of cytotoxic species including the inflammatory cytokines, INF-g, TNF-a, IL-1b and IL-6 and chemokines, most prominently CCL2 [10-12].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The deposition of fibrillar Ab in the AD brain results in the recruitment of microglia to the plaques owing to their expression of CCL2, which acts to attract microglia [82].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: In the past decade, drugs targeting the NRs, peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor g (PPARg) and liver X receptor (LXR) have shown to ameliorate pathogenesis in animal models of AD.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Recently, they have been shown to promote the degradation of the Ab peptides in the brain by activating genes responsible for reverse cholesterol transport [13].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Activation of these receptors has been shown to suppress microglial-mediated inflammatory responses both in vitro and in vivo.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: PPAR-g is involved in lipid storage, insulin sensitivity and energy metabolism and has been shown to promote adipocyte differentiation [21].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The synthetic TZD PPAR-g agonists are widely prescribed for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus, and have also been shown to be efficacious in a number of CNS disease models [21]. Currently, two TZD agonists, Actos (pioglitazone) and Avandia (rosiglitazone), are FDA approved for the treatment of diabetes.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The synthetic TZD PPAR-g agonists are widely prescribed for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus, and have also been shown to be efficacious in a number of CNS disease models [21]. Currently, two TZD agonists, Actos (pioglitazone) and Avandia (rosiglitazone), are FDA approved for the treatment of diabetes.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: When a higher dose of pioglitazone (7 days/40 mg/kg/day) was used in 10-monthold transgenic mice overexpressing the APP V717I mutation, a 20-- 25% decrease in plaque burden was observed with significant reduction in Ab42 levels within the brains of these animals [61].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Furthermore, the treatment of APP/PS1 mouse model of AD with pioglitazone (80 mg/kg/day) for 9 days lowered plaque burden by ~ 50% and reversed behavioral deficits in contextual fear conditioning assay.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Pedersen and Flynn examined the effects of rosiglitazone and found that activation of PPAR-g ameliorated behavioral deficits in the Tg2576 AD mouse model. However, these animals displayed no changes in plaque pathology, but had reduced brain Ab42 levels.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: These animals were treated with a low dose of rosiglitazone (3 mg/kg/ day) for 12 weeks and evaluated for plaque deposition and behavior. These animals displayed an approximate 50% decrease in amyloid deposition, a decrease in Ab oligomers, preservation of pre and postsynaptic proteins and the attenuation of cognitive deficits in the Morris water maze.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The authors argue that the effects of rosiglitazone were due to the activation of the wnt signaling cascade which they show by an increase in b-catenin expression and a decrease in GSK-3b levels [63].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The authors argue that the effects of rosiglitazone were due to the activation of the wnt signaling cascade which they show by an increase in b-catenin expression and a decrease in GSK-3b levels [63].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: While the authors did not detect an increase in ApoE levels in the treated animals, they did observe a modest increase in ABCA1 levels and argue that the enhanced Ab clearance could be attributed to an increase in lipidation of ApoE by ABCA1 [64].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: A Phase II clinical trial in which patients were treated with rosiglitazone for 6 months showed improvements in attention and memory retention, but only in patients who did not have an APOE4 allele.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: In a study reported by Kalinin et al., treatment of 5xFAD mice with the PPAR-d agonist, GW742, resulted in decreased plaque burden and an increase in the expression of two Ab proteases, neprilysin and IDE [72].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: In a study reported by Kalinin et al., treatment of 5xFAD mice with the PPAR-d agonist, GW742, resulted in decreased plaque burden and an increase in the expression of two Ab proteases, neprilysin and IDE [72].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: ATRA not only activates RXR but also activates the retinoic acid receptor.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: ATRA not only activates RXR but also activates the retinoic acid receptor.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Treatment of 5-month-old APP/PS1 mice for 8 weeks with ATRA (20 mg/kg/day) resulted in significant decreases in Ab deposition and tau phosphorylation in these mice. Additionally, it attenuated memory deficits seen in the Morris water maze [77].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Treatment of 5-month-old APP/PS1 mice for 8 weeks with ATRA (20 mg/kg/day) resulted in significant decreases in Ab deposition and tau phosphorylation in these mice. Additionally, it attenuated memory deficits seen in the Morris water maze [77].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Treatment of 5-month-old APP/PS1 mice for 8 weeks with ATRA (20 mg/kg/day) resulted in significant decreases in Ab deposition and tau phosphorylation in these mice. Additionally, it attenuated memory deficits seen in the Morris water maze [77].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: Bexarotene is a highly specific RXR agonist and is currently FDA approved with a favorable side effect profile. Studies in our laboratory have shown that treatment of APP/ PS1 animals with bexarotene for only 3 days results in a dramatic induction of ApoE and ABCA1 and the rapid reversal of AD-associated pathological hallmarks including reduction in amyloid deposition and deficits in behavior as well as neural networks.

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: More recently, a naturally occurring RXR agonist, honokiol, has been identified. This agonist is capable of activating RXR/LXR heterodimers and has been shown to induce the expression of ABCA1 and ApoE and should be tested in AD models [75,78].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: In this study, it was shown that samples from human AD brains as well as two aged mouse models of AD showed increased mRNA levels of the M2 markers, Arg1 and Ym1, when compared to age matched controls [101].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The Ab peptide is generated by the sequential cleavage of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) by the b and g secretases, resulting in the generation of peptides 40 or 42 amino acids in length [2].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: LXR receptors are activated by oxysterols, most prominently hydroxylated forms of cholesterol, and play a critical role in the control of whole body cholesterol homeostasis, as well as exerting potent anti-inflammatory actions [26].

citation.db_name: Nuclear receptors as therapeutic targets for Alzheimer's disease.

links.evidence: The M2c macrophages are thought to be in an ‘acquired deactivation’ state induced by IL-10, TGF-b, glucocorticoids or contact with apoptotic cells, and are associated with a suppression of the innate immune response.
